class_notes:
(Same as MUS 303 1)
Black Music:
Music and Performance in the African Diaspora is an interdisciplinary course exploring critical perspectives on Black music, dance, and culture in the US and abroad. We will build a critique of cultural production emphasizing an intersectional framework and critique of oppression via black studies, black feminisms, and sound studies. This class will bring together various media, social science, film, and art as we discuss legacies of blues, jazz, funk, hip hop, and techno. We will work toward a broad definition of black music to consider its history and global circulation.
course_description: This course considers the idea of Black Music. What is it? What does it sound like?  Who created it? These musical questions are set in the context of an equally complicated web of ideas about race and the relationship between racial expectation and black music/cultural production.
